The tip of the tongue is just as interesting. The tongue is covered in a gluey substance that is a non-neutonian fluid, although opposite to the usual corn starch/water. When it hits the prey, the saliva is under high pressure, so it's a liquid. While liquid the saliva gets into all of the little cracks and gaps of the insects body, however after impact the saliva is no longer under pressure so it goes back to being a solid forming a solid grip on the insect when the tongue retracts. When in the mouth the chameleon closes its jaw and compresses it's mouth to make it high pressure. This releases the insect by transforming the saliva back to a liquid so it can be eaten.

Just using the rocket that hangs in the background I managed to find out how long the time was between the jump cut at 7:52 and 7:53. I assumed that the rocket managed to turn a total of 15 degrees within 3 seconds. So what I did is is estimated the total amount of distance that it rotated after the jump cut. It looked to be a total 180 degrees so all I had to do after that was take a 180 degrees and divided by 15 to get the total number of 3 second intervals then multiply that number by 3. And in total you took about a 36 second jump cut. Now that's getting 2x smarter on a day.
